messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 48 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Simultaneous Locomotion Mode Classification and Continuous Gait Phase Estimation for Transtibial Prostheses

Paper Abstract: Abstract Recognizing and identifying human locomotion is a critical step to ensuring fluent control of wearable robots, such as transtibial prostheses. In particular, classifying the intended locomotion mode and estimating the gait phase are key. In this work, a novel, interpretable, and computationally efficient algorithm is presented for simultaneously predicting locomotion mode and gait phase. Using able-bodied (AB) and transtibial prosthesis (PR) data, seven locomotion modes are tested including slow, medium, and fast level walking (0.6, 0.8, and 1.0 m/s), ramp ascent/descent (5 degrees), and stair ascent/descent (20 cm height). Overall classification accuracy was 99.1%percent\% and 99.3%percent\% for the AB and PR conditions, respectively. The average gait phase error across all data was less than 4%percent\%. Exploiting the structure of the data, computational efficiency reached 2.91 Œºùúá\mus per time step. The time complexity of this algorithm scales as O‚Äã(N‚ãÖM)ùëÇ‚ãÖùëÅùëÄO(N\cdot M) with the number of locomotion modes MùëÄM and samples per gait cycle NùëÅN. This efficiency and high accuracy could accommodate a much larger set of locomotion modes (‚àºsimilar-to\sim 700 on Open-Source Leg Prosthesis) to handle the wide range of activities pursued by individuals during daily living.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 48 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 48"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Evaluating fluency in human‚Äìrobot collaboration",
        "Effects of user intent changes on onboard sensor measurements during exoskeleton-assisted walking",
        "Quantitative gait assessment with feature-rich diversity using two imu sensors",
        "Imu-based classification of parkinson‚Äôs disease from gait: A sensitivity analysis on sensor location and feature selection",
        "What is the best configuration of wearable sensors to measure spatiotemporal gait parameters in children with cerebral palsy?",
        "Profiling walking dysfunction in multiple sclerosis: characterisation, classification and progression over time",
        "Using measurements from wearable sensors for automatic scoring of parkinson‚Äôs disease motor states: Results from 7 patients",
        "Validation of an accelerometer to quantify a comprehensive battery of gait characteristics in healthy older adults and parkinson‚Äôs disease: toward clinical and at home use",
        "Control strategies for active lower extremity prosthetics and orthotics: a review",
        "Machine learning approaches for activity recognition and/or activity prediction in locomotion assistive devices‚Äîa systematic review",
        "A machine learning strategy for locomotion classification and parameter estimation using fusion of wearable sensors",
        "Imu-based locomotion mode identification for transtibial prostheses, orthoses, and exoskeletons",
        "A phase variable approach for imu-based locomotion activity recognition",
        "A training method for locomotion mode prediction using powered lower limb prostheses",
        "A locomotion intent prediction system based on multi-sensor fusion",
        "Continuous locomotion-mode identification for prosthetic legs based on neuromuscular‚Äìmechanical fusion",
        "Multiclass real-time intent recognition of a powered lower limb prosthesis",
        "Locomotion mode recognition algorithm based on gaussian mixture model using imu sensors",
        "Intent recognition in a powered lower limb prosthesis using time history information",
        "Delaying ambulation mode transition decisions improves accuracy of a flexible control system for powered knee-ankle prosthesis",
        "A cnn-based method for intent recognition using inertial measurement units and intelligent lower limb prosthesis",
        "Classification of gait type based on deep learning using various sensors with smart insole",
        "A strain gauge based locomotion mode recognition method using convolutional neural network",
        "Transfer learning for efficient intent prediction in lower-limb prosthetics: A strategy for limited datasets",
        "Design and control of a powered knee and ankle prosthesis",
        "Finite-state impedance and direct myoelectric control for robotic ankle prostheses: Comparing their performance and exploring their combination",
        "A review of gait phase detection algorithms for lower limb prostheses",
        "Experimental effective shape control of a powered transfemoral prosthesis",
        "Towards biomimetic virtual constraint control of a powered prosthetic leg",
        "A survey of phase variable candidates of human locomotion",
        "Data-driven phase-based control of a powered knee-ankle prosthesis for variable-incline stair ascent and descent",
        "A novel control algorithm for wearable robotics using phase plane invariants",
        "Calibration of a tibia-based phase variable for control of robotic transtibial prostheses",
        "Hybrid volitional control of a robotic transtibial prosthesis using a phase variable impedance controller",
        "Real-time gait phase estimation for robotic hip exoskeleton control during multimodal locomotion",
        "Noninvasive human-prosthesis interfaces for locomotion intent recognition: A review",
        "Simultaneous bayesian recognition of locomotion and gait phases with wearable sensors",
        "Locomotion mode identification and gait phase estimation for exoskeletons during continuous multilocomotion tasks",
        "Gait pattern identification and phase estimation in continuous multilocomotion mode based on inertial measurement units",
        "Continuous locomotion mode recognition and gait phase estimation based on a shank-mounted imu with artificial neural networks",
        "Real-time assistive control via imu locomotion mode detection in a soft exosuit: An effective approach to enhance walking metabolic efficiency",
        "Effects of locomotion mode recognition errors on volitional control of powered above-knee prostheses",
        "Evaluation of function, performance, and preference as transfemoral amputees transition from mechanical to microprocessor control of the prosthetic knee",
        "A novel approach for real-time gait events detection using developed wireless foot sensor module",
        "SlidingWindowGaitEstimation - Example code",
        "Controlling powered prosthesis kinematics over continuous transitions between walk and stair ascent",
        "A ‚Äúsmart‚Äù undershirt for tracking upper body motions: Task classification and angle estimation",
        "Wearable sensor clothing for body movement measurement during physical activities in healthcare"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 48 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Simultaneous Locomotion Mode Classification and Continuous Gait Phase Estimation for Transtibial Prostheses, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
